questions.question_text:
You have 25 computers that run Windows 10 Pro.

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You need to upgrade the computers to Windows 11 Enterprise by using an in-place upgrade. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you use?

choices.B: Microsoft Configuration Manager and a custom image of Windows 11 Enterprise
choices.A: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) and a default image of Windows 11 Enterprise

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Autopilot does not upgrade Windows version. The only approach listed to perform upgrade in-place is MDT with DEFAULT image

comments.content: The answers is B - Configuration manager

Autopilot does upgrade to Win 11, and there is no MDT in Azure AD, but the least Administrative effort is Subscription Activation, so the answer is D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The question doesn't say anywhere that they have on-premise infrastructure setup which is needed for MDT and Config Manager. so both options A & B are gone. 
Windows Autopilot can upgrade your computer from Windows 10 Pro to Windows 11 Pro, but to upgrade Pro to Windows Enterprise edition, a Subscription is needed. 
So correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Lots of debate on this one, but I think D is correct. Here's why (with the help of chat GBT)
-You have Windows 10 Pro devices
-You have Microsoft 365 E5 (which includes Windows 11 Enterprise licensing)
-You want to upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise
-You want to minimize admin effort (I think this piece is key here)
-You want to do an in-place upgrade (keep files, apps, settings)

Subscription Activation allows devices with Windows 10/11 Pro to automatically upgrade to Enterprise edition without reinstalling the OS — as long as:
-The device is Azure AD-joined or hybrid joined
-The user has an M365 E3 or E5 license
-The base OS is Windows Pro (which your 25 devices already have)

The other options are wrong because they either don't support in place upgrades, or have too many steps/too complex to be considered the least effort solution

Why Update the Deployment Share?
The "Update Deployment Share" process in MDT regenerates the necessary files, including the WinPE boot image files, with the new settings.
This action rebuilds the LiteTouch boot images (LiteTouchPE_x86.wim and LiteTouchPE_x64.wim) located in the deployment share's Boot folder.

discussion.content:
To generate a new set of WinPE boot image files with the updated settings in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), you should:

B. From the Advanced Configuration node, create new media.

Here's how you can do it:

Open the Deployment Workbench.

In the left pane, expand the "Advanced Configuration" node.

Right-click on "Media" and select "New Media."

Follow the wizard to create new media. During this process, you can customize the WinPE settings and add PowerShell support as needed.

discussion.content:
The Enable-PSRemoting cmdlet performs the following operations:

Runs the Set-WSManQuickConfig cmdlet, which performs the following tasks:
Starts the WinRM service.
Sets the startup type on the WinRM service to Automatic.
Creates a listener to accept requests on any IP address.
Enables a firewall exception for WS-Management communications.
Creates the simple and long name session endpoint configurations if needed.
Enables all session configurations.
Changes the security descriptor of all session configurations to allow remote access.
Restarts the WinRM service to make the preceding changes effective.
